metadata.title: A Practical Guide on Exploratory Data Analysis: Historical Temperatures of Cities | by Soner Yıldırım | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: A Practical Guide on Exploratory Data Analysis: Historical Temperatures of Cities
metadata.description: I have recently come across an interesting dataset on Kaggle that contains historical temperatures of 321 cities from 1995 to 2020. I thought it would be a good practice to explore this dataset amid…

all_paragraphs: I have recently come across an interesting dataset on Kaggle that contains historical temperatures of 321 cities from 1995 to 2020. I thought it would be a good practice to explore this dataset amid discussions about global warming. You can access the dataset here on Kaggle.
I will use pandas which is a python data analysis library and plotly python (plotly.py) which is an open-source plotting library built on plotly javascript (plotly.js).

Let’s start with importing the libraries and reading the dataset into a pandas dataframe. When I read the description of the dataset, I found out that the value “-99” was used as a missing value marker for temperatures. We can use na_values parameter of read_csv function to replace “-99” with standard missing value representation of pandas which is NaN. We can also do this replacement after creating the dataframe but I think its easier to handle while reading the data.
The year range is supposed to be 1995–2020. We can confirm it using value_counts.
We have some misinformation with years “201” and “200”. I think these are just typos and represent a very small part of the data.

The total number of rows in these years is 440 which is very small compared to 2906327 rows. Furthermore, we can’t know what the true values are for these years. Thus, we can eliminate the rows whose years are 201 or 200.
Let’s also look for missing values.

It is normal to have lots of missing values in “state” column because most countries do not have state concepts. So, we will ignore missing states. The other column that have missing values is “AvgTemperature”. The dataset is structured in a way that consecutive rows change by day so missing temperature values can be forward filled. For missing temperatures, we will assume the average daily temperature is same as the previous day. One downside of this approach would occur if the first record for a city is missing. We will use fillna and pass “ffill” to the method parameter.
The dataset contains “Fahrenheit” temperatures but I’m more familiar with “Celcius” values. Let’s add one more column by converting fahrenheit degrees to celcius.

We know that the countries in Africa have the highest temperatures in general. But, is there a big difference among different regions in the world? We can check the average temperature of regions between 1995 and 2020 using groupby function.

The average temperature in Africa is approximately twice as high as average temperature in Europe. The averages agree with our geographical knowledge. As we move away from the equator, temperature decreases.
How about yearly values? Is global warming real? Let’s first take the yearly averages of regions.
We can now show the trend on a line plot.
There is a slight increase in all regions. We ignore 2020 because it is not completed yet. It seems like global warming is real. We can also compare the averages between 1995 and 2019.
The average temperatures have increased in all regions. It seems like the global warming is real.

One of the nice things about the shape and movement of the earth is that countries in different hemispheres have different seasons at the same time. While it is winter in Europe, Australia enjoys summer. Let’s check if we can see this trend in average monthly temperatures.
We now have average monthly temperatures of regions. Let’s plot them.

We definitely observe effect of different seasons in north and south hemispheres. In some regions, a dramatic change in temperature occurs in different seasons whereas Africa and South/Central America do not have significant fluctuations. This is related to the geographical location and size of these regions.
One interesting thing to chech is hottest and coldest cities in the world. Here is the hottest 10:
You may be suprised that the temperature of the hottest city turns out be 30 degrees celcius. We can see the coldest 10 by selecting the last 10 rows using [-10:].
Most of the coldest cities are in Canada or US.

The average temperature has increased all over the world in the last 25 years. Global warming is a serious issue as emphasized by scientists over and over. As we have seen, the real measurements agree with the concern of scientists and researchers. We need to take this seriously.
Thank you for reading. Please let me know if you have any feedback.
